coredata.dc:title: Effect of long-range hydrodynamic and direct intermacromolecular forces on translational diffusion
coredata.dc:creator: Lee, Wylie I.
Schurr, J.Michael
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Within the framework of recently formulated microscopic theories of macromolecular diffusion it is shown that hydrodynamic forces act always to diminish the influence of direct forces, but never to reverse the sign of the correction term due to direct forces alone. Although the correction term D(k) to the intrinsic diffusion coefficient may vary with scattering vector |k|, it is shown that a reversal in sigh of the correction term with increasing |k|, if it occurs, must be associated with an amplitude of less than 10% of the correction term at |k| = 0. At |k| = 0 direct repulsive forces are predicted to always increase the apparent diffusion constant, even after accounting for hydrodynamic interactions. Although experiments on polylysine (1 mg/ml) at salt concentrations above 0.01 M are in qualitative accord with the theory, below 10−3 M salt the apparent diffusion coefficient is reduced by a factor of about 20, concomitant with a much reduced intensity of scattered light. The strong contradiction of the theory implied by this observation is attributed to a dramatic rise in Stokes friction arising from long-range interionic forces in the low-salt solutions.

I. hitroduction The microscopic tlieoiy of diffusion in solutions of macromolecules has been significantly advanced by two recent articles [1,21. From an N-particle diffusion equation including hydrodynumic interactions in the Oseen tensor approximation, Altenberger and Deutch [1~ derived a kinetic equation for the one-particle distribution function in terms of the two-particle distribution function, and showed also that hydrodynamic interactions exert no influence on diffusion in the absence of direct intermolecular forces. Beginning with an intuitive generalization of the one-particle Fokker Planck equation incorporating direct intermolecular forces, but neglecting hydrodynamic interactions, Phillies 121 derived for long wavelengths the generalized Stokes--Einstein relation for non-ideal (i.e. directly interacting) macromolecules. There remains to be answered the interesting question of how the generalized Stokes Einstein equation (for long wavelengths) is modified by hydrodynamic interactions. Especially, one would like to know whether the effect .)f direct repulsive forces (alone) to enhance the rate of diffusion could ever be overcompensated, or re- versed in sign, by the inclusion of hydrodynamic interactions. Both Altenberger and Deutch and Phillies investigated the problem of oscillatory fluctuations, and the depen- dence of the apparent diffusion coefficient on wave-vector k. Again the question of whether hydrodynamic inter- actions could ever reverse the sign of the correction term due to direct interactions alone is left open. Also there is the additional question of whether the correction terni changes sign as k increases from the k O limit. In as- sessing the validity of the kinetic equation of Altenberger and Deutch it is desirable to have some idea of the pertinent upper limits for changes in the correction term as the wave-vector increases from k = O to arbitrarily large values. Experimental observations The relaxation of concentration fluctuations in solutions of poly-L.lysine H13r (M = 200000 daltons, d.p. 955) has been studied over a wide range of pH, salt, and polyion concentration by dynamic light scattering [3 5 J. For 1 mg/mI solutions of polylysine the apparent diffusion coefficient at pH 6 was found to increase from 1 .4 to 2.8 X 1O~ cm2/s (i.e. by a factor of 2) as the salt (NaBr) concentration was decreased from O.2M to about 0.01 M [4). Since the strength and range of the repulsive interactions are expected to increase with decreasing salt, this result is qualitatively in accord with the theoretical predictions above. The autocorrelation functions were in- variably single exponentiats within the limits of detection capability, and accurately proportional 1k 12. Below 103M salt the intensity of scattered light was reduced by a factor of 2.2 to 2.5, and the relaxation of concentration fluctuations, though still approximately single exponential and nearly proportional to I k 12, was ~ 20 times slower than in the salt range above O.lM. That is,D5~0 dropped from 1.4 X i0~~ to about 7.1 X lO-~ cm2 s~ in the low-salt phase. This remarkable behavior could be eliminated by addition of salt and regenerated upon salt-removal by dialysis. lt was also observed for both pH-annealed [4] and non-annealed samples, and for much higher polylysirie concentrations (6.5 m~/m1), where it persisted to higher salt concentrations. Details of these and similar findings for different molecular weight and different polyelectrolyte samples, as weil as features of the transi- tion from the low-salt to the normal phase will be described elsewhere [6] . The critical feature of these obser- vations is that, when the Debye length (calculated from the salt only) becomes roughly comparable to or greater than lite spacing between polyions, which have effective Stokes radii of 160 A in 0.2M Nal3r, then a terrific slow- down of the diffusion occurs, concomitant with a cor iderable decrease in the intensity of light scattered at all angles. As the reduced intensity is a clear indication that repulsive forces prevail, the prediction of the theory above is very strongly contradicted. 73 Volume 38, number I CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEiTERS 15.Februaiy 1976 One may conclude that the reduced diffusion equation of Altenberger and Deutch, eq. (1) above, is by itself inadequate for situations in which long-range repulsive forces prevail. lt is our speculation that under these con- ditions intermacromolecular forces make the major contribution to the Stokes friction of the polyions, which is, of course, a feature not incorporated into the original N-particle diffusion equation adopted by Altenberger and Deutch. In view of recent work [9) elaborating the statistical mechanical foundations of the theory of macromolecular brownian motion, it seems probable that the fi)nn of the reduced diffusion equation employed by Altenberger and Deutch is valid, but that a proper accounting for the effect of direct intermolecular forces on the Stokes friction factor is lacking. Though less dramatic in quantitative ternis, the recent results of Schaaffer and Herne [7J for very dilute solu- tions of charged spherical viruses also clearly contradict the theoretical predictions above. The correctibn term to the intrinsic diffusion coefficient changes sign in their study as the scattering angle increases, but tire magnitude of the cross-over substantially exceeds 10% of the k = O limiting value (i.e. by a factor of 3), which is contrary to the theory. Althoug 1 these results might be reconciled with the theory by postulating a modest increase (~lO%) in particle radius with decreasing ionic strength, there appears to be no way of reconciling the polylysine results. lt can be argued that the theory considered here is incomplete for polyelcctrolyte solutions in which there are actually two (or more) ionic components, polyions and counterions. Although the theory presented above can be readily generalized to include the counterions, leading to coupled diffusion equations for polyions and counterions, we have not been able to evaluate the limiting behavior for the slowest relaxing component. However, on intuitive grounds it is not expected that incorporation of the much faster diffusing counterions could significantly decrease the rate of the slowest relaxation. Indeed, we have recently [4,61 solved the three simultaneous linearized Fokker Planck e~quations for polylons, co-ins, and by-ions of the added salt all diffusing under the influence of a common electrostatic potential determined by Poisson s equation in the conzinuou~ charge approximation. The procedure is essentially identical to that employed earlier by Scimurr [8] for symmetrical electrolytes, and adopted recently by Phillies [10] for tire problem of polyions and counterions. For very dilute polylon solutions in the presence of considerable added salt the slowest of the three relaxation rates corresponds to the result of Stephen [11]. Under no circumstances, whether in the presence or absence rf salt, do any of the fluctuating modes relax with a rate slower than k2D~, where is the intrinsic (hythodynamic) diffusion coefficient of the polyion. in view of the wide disparity between the results for polylysine and the predictions of any of the theories it appears that the usual Fokker Planck equation with the isolated-molecule friction factor is not applicable when the intermacro-ion electrical forces are unscreened.
